Border Colours

It's possible to change the colour of borders by using the bor-x css class, replacing x with the colour desired.

The colours available to choose from depend on the colours module, and any customisation that has been applied.

.bor-x
.bor-cream
.bor-wht
.bor-white
.bor-light
.bor-grey
.bor-dark
.bor-pitch
.bor-black
.bor-blk
.bor-silver
.bor-gold
.bor-yellow
.bor-orange
.bor-red
.bor-pink
.bor-violet
.bor-purple
.bor-blue
.bor-teal
.bor-mint
.bor-green

Usage example

Without any customisation, Eezo will come with the classes described above, here's and example of how to use them

<body class="bor-1 bor-purple">
  has a purple border.
</body>

Customising

Default Classes

To change the prefix in front of border colours, you may use the $border-color-prop variable.

// change the class prefix to .bclr-
$border-color-prop: "bclr";

Custom Border Colours

Just like text colours, borders will also inherit the default $colors map. You may customise the colours used for borders by supplying a $border-colors map instead.

// change the border colours to only red and blue.
$text-colors: (
  red: #ff0000,
  blue: #0000ff
);

Combined

After changing the prefix property and the map of colours in the previous two customisations, we would end up with the following css.

/* would result in css like: */
.bclr-red   { color: #ff0000; }
.bclr-blue  { color: #0000ff; }

view the source on github: /src/components/border/_color.scss
